This is regarding PR mathlib4#16094 and future PRs which will depend on it.

The IsSumSq predicate is defined inductively by S := 0 | a * a + S. It is easy to prove that {x : IsSumSq x} forms an AddSubmonoid directly from the definition.

I need more complex results such as "a product of sums of squares is a sum of squares". Here are two reasonable-looking ways to prove them:
(1) Use induction. Here we can use either the raw definition or closure induction on {x : IsSumSq x} = AddSubmonoid.closure {x : IsSquare x}, but they yield essentially the same proofs.
(2) Prove that IsSumSq y is equivalent to the existence of a finite sum y = ∑ i ∈ I, x i * xi. Then rewrite and make use of existing lemmas about sums.

The main advantage of option (1) is that it follows the principle of avoiding explicit closure representations in favour of an inductive argument.

The main advantage of option (2) is that the proofs are shorter (in the code editor) and cleaner (for instance requiring no side lemmas). The proofs are also (aesthetically?) closer to "pen and paper" proofs.

Personally I'm happy to take either approach, but I've got advice in both directions, so I'm looking for thoughts here.

For reference:
PR with option (1): https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16094/commits/57adeca7807c1bd21c694ea6cec4a590ffb997bd
PR with option (2): https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16094/commits/b3cae9405d6f0f1580305b6fb2bdb8333074c38e
My impression is that mathlib has far more of the (1)-like approach than the (2)-like approach, and I guess mathlib likes shorter and cleaner proofs.

lol I got (1) and (2) the wrong way around above ^ sorry
fixed!
Another advantage of the second approach is that it does not rely on the particular way IsSumSq happens to be defined in mathlib.
OK well just to be clear, I meant that mathlib has a lot more induction and a lot less reducing to Finset.sum .

Mitchell Lee said:

Another advantage of the second approach is that it does not rely on the particular way IsSumSq happens to be defined in mathlib.

Well, I'm already using an alternative induction scheme
S := 0 | IsSquare a → a + S
which is equivalent to submonoid closure induction. So I don't think this is a big consideration here (you'd have to reprove the equivalence to the sum representation just like you'd have to reprove the induction scheme). Even if someone wants to use the vanilla induction scheme provided by Lean, we can always abstract it out if the definition changes.
For (1), the IsSumSq.mul lemma can be generalized to "if S is a submonoid, then (Subsemiring.closure S).toAddSubmonoid = AddSubmonoid.closure S.
And we probably have this.
(or it should be added)

We have https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Subsemiring/Basic.html#Subsemiring.coe_closure_eq and https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Subsemiring/Basic.html#Subsemiring.closure_addSubmonoid_closure

@Artie Khovanov I think we should just have (1) + (2). Of course only one of them can be the definition. But soon afterwards, you prove that it is equivalent to the other version. And from that point onwards, everybody can choose to work with whatever suits them best.

OK a new example problem (since @Yury G. Kudryashov correctly pointed out my one is already in mathlib, oops):
Show that the condition
(∑ i ∈ I, x i * x i) = 0 → ∀ i ∈ I, x i = 0
("the ring is formally real") is characterised by
IsSumSq S → x * x + S = 0 → x = 0.
Can't you drop the LHS of that ∧\land∧? It's a special case of the RHS, with S=0S = 0S=0.
∑ i ∈ I, x i * x i = 0 → i ∈ I → i = 0 -- careful with parsing that thing :-) (sums eat as much as they can)
Do you mean x i = 0, not i = 0?
Could you please write a #mwe with theorem you want to prove?

Here is an MWE of the sort of result I want to prove:

import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset
import Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.Defs

/- Definition taken from Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.SumsOfSquares for clarity -/
inductive IsSumSq [Mul R] [Add R] [Zero R] : R → Prop
  | zero                              : IsSumSq 0
  | sq_add {a s : R} (hs : IsSumSq s) : IsSumSq (a * a + s)

class IsFormallyReal (R : Type*) [AddCommMonoid R] [Mul R] : Prop where
  eq_zero_of_sum_of_squares_eq_zero {ι : Type} {I : Finset ι} {a : ι → R}
    (hx : ∑ i ∈ I, a i * a i = 0) {i : ι} (hi : i ∈ I) : a i = 0

export IsFormallyReal (eq_zero_of_sum_of_squares_eq_zero)

/- Here are the nontrivial forward implications I want.
Really I want the second one, but
I think the easiest way to prove it purely inductively is via the first. -/

theorem induction₁ {R : Type*} [NonUnitalNonAssocCommSemiring R] [IsFormallyReal R]
    {s : R} (hs : IsSumSq s)
    {ι : Type*} {I : Finset ι} (a : ι → R)
    (h : (∑ i ∈ I, a i * a i) + s = 0) : s = 0 := by
  induction hs
  case zero => rfl
  case sq_add a b s hs ih => sorry

theorem induction₂ {R : Type*} [NonUnitalNonAssocCommSemiring R] [IsFormallyReal R]
    {s₁ s₂ : R} (hs₁ : IsSumSq s₁) (hs₂ : IsSumSq s₂) (h : s₁ + s₂ = 0) : s₁ = 0 := by sorry

@Artie Khovanov I added some API lemmas, do you think those are helpful?

import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset
import Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.Defs
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Fin

/- Definition taken from Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.SumsOfSquares for clarity -/
inductive IsSumSq [Mul R] [Add R] [Zero R] : R → Prop
  | zero                              : IsSumSq 0
  | sq_add {a s : R} (hs : IsSumSq s) : IsSumSq (a * a + s)

namespace IsSumSq

variable {R : Type*}

protected lemma sq [Mul R] [AddZeroClass R] (a : R) : IsSumSq (a * a) := by
  simpa using IsSumSq.zero.sq_add (a := a)

protected lemma add [Mul R] [AddMonoid R] {s₁ s₂ : R} (h₁ : IsSumSq s₁) (h₂ : IsSumSq s₂) : IsSumSq (s₁ + s₂) := by
  induction h₁ with
  | zero => rwa [zero_add]
  | sq_add hs ih => rw [add_assoc]; exact ih.sq_add

protected lemma sum [Mul R] [AddCommMonoid R] {ι : Type*} (I : Finset ι) (a : ι → R) : IsSumSq (∑ i ∈ I, a i * a i) := by
  classical
  induction I using Finset.induction_on with
  | empty => simpa using IsSumSq.zero
  | insert h ih => simpa [Finset.sum_insert h] using ih.sq_add

protected lemma sum_exists [NonUnitalNonAssocSemiring R] {s : R} (hs : IsSumSq s) :
    ∃ (n : ℕ) (a : Fin n → R), s = (∑ i, a i * a i) := by
  induction hs with
  | zero => use 0, 0; simp
  | sq_add hs ih =>
    rename_i r a
    obtain ⟨n, a, rfl⟩ := ih
    use n+1, Fin.cons r a
    simp [Fin.sum_univ_succ]

end IsSumSq

class IsFormallyReal (R : Type*) [AddCommMonoid R] [Mul R] : Prop where
  eq_zero_of_sum_of_squares_eq_zero {ι : Type} {I : Finset ι} {a : ι → R}
    (hx : ∑ i ∈ I, a i * a i = 0) {i : ι} (hi : i ∈ I) : a i = 0

export IsFormallyReal (eq_zero_of_sum_of_squares_eq_zero)

/- Here are the nontrivial forward implications I want.
Really I want the second one, but
I think the easiest way to prove it purely inductively is via the first. -/

theorem induction₁ {R : Type*} [NonUnitalNonAssocCommSemiring R] [IsFormallyReal R]
    {s : R} (hs : IsSumSq s)
    {ι : Type*} {I : Finset ι} (a : ι → R)
    (h : (∑ i ∈ I, a i * a i) + s = 0) : s = 0 := by
  induction hs
  case zero => rfl
  case sq_add a b s hs ih => sorry

theorem induction₂ {R : Type*} [NonUnitalNonAssocCommSemiring R] [IsFormallyReal R]
    {s₁ s₂ : R} (hs₁ : IsSumSq s₁) (hs₂ : IsSumSq s₂) (h : s₁ + s₂ = 0) : s₁ = 0 := by sorry

Johan Commelin said:

Artie Khovanov I added some API lemmas, do you think those are helpful?

That last lemma (sum_exists) is (a special case of) the lemma I am RFCing whether to add.

I don't think the first 3 lemmas are particularly useful for proving the induction₁ and induction₂, since they go in the wrong direction. The last lemma sum_exists makes the induction principles very easy to prove, but that's the point of the RFC.

My opinion is that either you avoid big operators completely (including in IsFormallyReal, defining it as IsSumSq S → x * x + S = 0 → x = 0 instead), or you use them, and if you use them for IsFormallyReal there's no point in avoiding their usage in the proofs

Yeah I'm inclined to agree. I wouldn't want to define IsFormallyReal inductively, because to me the equivalence of the standard and sum-free definitions isn't really trivial. But I'm open to other opinions on that as well!
